literal_meaning: To take the bull by the horns.
example: When faced with the issues at work, she decided to take the bull by the horns.

idiom: At slå to fluer med ét smæk
literal_meaning: To hit two flies with one swat.
figurative_meaning: To accomplish two tasks at once.
example: By combining errands, he managed to hit two flies with one swat.

idiom: At have en finger med i spillet
literal_meaning: To have a finger in the game.
example: He always has a finger in the game when it comes to family decisions.

figurative_meaning: To offer something valuable to those who won't appreciate it.
example: Giving him advice is like throwing pearls before swine; he never listens.

idiom: At gå over åen efter vand
literal_meaning: To go over the river for water.
figurative_meaning: To go out of your way for something that is easily obtainable.
example: You don't need to go over åen efter vand; the solution is right here.

idiom: At have det som blommen i et æg
literal_meaning: To have it like the yolk in an egg.
figurative_meaning: To be in a very comfortable or safe situation.
example: After moving into her new apartment, she feels like blommen i et æg.

figurative_meaning: To be in a precarious or risky situation.
example: With his job security uncertain, he feels like he's on glatis.

literal_meaning: To see fate in the cards.
figurative_meaning: To predict future events based on current signs.
example: She believes she can see skæbnen i kortene when she reads tarot cards.

idiom: At være som en fisk på land
literal_meaning: To be like a fish on land.
figurative_meaning: To feel out of place or uncomfortable.
example: In that meeting, I felt like a fish on land; I didn't belong there.
